What did Eastern Canadian pioneer eat?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name Dorothy W. Baldwin
Address Gladstone, Sask.
Birthplace Higham, Hampshire, England

1. Introductory Questions
   We have been here since 1910.
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada?
   Where did you set up housekeeping?
   Where had you been living before that?
   For how many people did you prepare meals?
   How far was it to your nearest store?
   How often could a visit be made to the store?
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. Flour and Other Grain Products
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
   In what quantities did you buy it?
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
   How much did you use Graham flour?
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally?
   How far away was that year?
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? Oats? Whole wheat?
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
   How did you grind it?

3. Other Questions
   What did you do for recreation?
   What did you do for entertainment?
   What did you do for exercise?
   What did you do for education?
   What did you do for religion?
   What did you do for leisure?
1. INTERVIEW IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Name: Dorothy W. Baker
Address: 123 Main Street, Anytown, USA
Date: October 15, 1945

2. FLOUR AND THEIR GRAIN PRODUCTS

Have you used any flour in the last year? Yes/No

If yes, what type of flour did you use?

Handwritten notes:

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 pounds.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.40.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.

What size or tin of syrup did you usually buy? 5 oz.

At what price? I think about $0.75 for 5 lbs. $0.60 for 10 lbs.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Most of our milk was from cows.

Was there any butter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef bought frozen in winter, pork cured in summer, our own pigs.

How did you get fresh meat? We only got it at killing time.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? Dry cured pork till about 1938 when we started canning our own beef.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? None.

Did you use game? Not very much. Rabbit.

For how long? Mostly in the winter from 1916-1921.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not much.

Has the fish been fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh frozen in winter and rabbit sometimes & a little salmon.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

I think about $1.50. Could you get potatoes at the store? I don't know. I think some times we could have ...?

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? ...?

What weight? ...?

What was the price of prunes? ...?

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? mostly apricots, a few dried apples, loganberries, also currants and some raisins.

8. PRESERVING

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ...?

To what extent? all the saskatoons I can get, also with loganberries.

Did you make your own vinegar? ...?

How far was this water from your home? [Handwritten: 1 mile]

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) [Handwritten: pail]

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (gall., river, slough)

If so, was this water from your house?

Was it brought to the house (gall., barrel, tank)...

Have you had any changes which have taken place since you first started householding, giving dates where possible.

In 1913 we got our first well. We now have our house not have never had 2 others dug at about the same distance.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? We always bought it.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Good ash?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Kel's naptha & sunlight.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Mostly wood.

Where did you get your fuel? We came here to our homestead in May 1910 and have been getting wood from the back ever since.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping. Giving dates where possible, we have always used a little coal in winter; we used about 3 tons each winter. In 1914 we got a coal oil stove to use in the hot weather, and in 1947 I got a gas stove, but we still use the wood in the cook stove, and coal in the heater in winter.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) We always had a heater with cooking.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No, before and a cook stove since 1910.

By whom was your first cook stove made? I do not know, the heater is a Smith.

What year was it purchased? 1910. Price? $10.00.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Mostly make enamel and some tin frying pans.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? 1905 in Manitoba.

Aluminum? 1913.
What kind of laundry soap did you use? Soap.

That year did you use in this until? Until 1911 we used soap.

We always had an outdoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Yes.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

What year was it purchased? 1906.

What types of utensils did you use? (List) Tin, wood, iron, glass, china, earthenware, porcelain bowls, other.

For preserving food? (china, earthenware, porcelain bowls, other)

Then did you first see metal? 1905 in March.

After that? 1913.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Brown sugar and icing sugar are now in bags as well as bulk. Table salt can also be bought in cardboard cartons. Then lettuce and celery come in cellophane. Also bacon is sliced and wrapped now, and celery, corn can be got in tins now, also many more kinds of canned soup can be got.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: rolled oat porridge, buttered toast, coffee, dinner: boiled potatoes, beef, chicken or rabbit, roasted, with gravy, and rice or tapioca pudding, supper: boiled eggs, bread & butter, stewed prunes or apples, or the dried ones.

This would be in the winter 1910-11.

Father 38, mother 33, brother 12, me 7, sister 3 months.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

I have never given a Christmas dinner myself. Mother used to have guests for Christmas dinner in 1912 and for some years after, a couple of young bachelors, or a young married couple. In the late 20s, we would have roast chicken, plum pudding, mince pie, mashed potatoes, bread, butter, and tea, canned tomatoes or corn.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No
16. **SOMETHING ABOUT CHRISTMAS**

   I remember the Christmas dinner which you received in the orphanage and schoolhouse. You were given a special dinner (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the Christmas year. You were also given a special dinner at Easter. Since then, you have always had a special dinner at Christmas.

   This would be our first Christmas dinner in our new home. We would have roast chicken, ham, turkey, mashed potatoes, bread, butter, and tea, canned tomatoes, corn, and fruit cake.

   That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in our new home?
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Much as we have always done only now from times use the sweetened puddings instead of rice tapioca or macaroni being alone to do all the housework freed something quicker, and too in the morning we use prepared cereals instead of porridge.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

About 1935 we started using prepared cereals for breakfast, and at that time we used a lot of canned vegetables as we were unable to grow many as the weather was too dry, but we have our own home grown ones now and in the early days we used more dried fruit, after 1920 we started to buy the fresh fruit and can it.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We used to trap rabbits a lot in the years from 1916 to 1920 for food, and we used to cure our own pork, now we do not get rabbits, and we keep our meat in the cold storage locker in the early days too mother used to make boiled puddings tied in a cloth, now we always boil them in pudding bowls.

I am afraid this account is not as early as you would like, but this district was not settled till 1906, and I was quite young when I was brought here in 1910. From your subscriber D.W. Baker.
